item.title: Week 5 Summary
item.description: Maximum Likelihood (ML) ML estimates of variance components tend to be biased downward (smaller than they should be), making us more likely to pick models with simpler random effects structures than we should. We choose ML when we need to compare two nested based on their fixed effects since we cannot do likelihood ratio tests with models fit with REML unless the fixed effects are exactly the same. Restricted maximum likelihood (REML)

item.title: Week 4 Summary
item.description: Maximum Likelihood Estimation “Maximum likelihood estimation is a method that determines values for the parameters of a model. The parameter values are found such that they maximise the likelihood that they maximise the likelihood that process described by the model produced the data that were actually observed.” (Jonny Brooks-Bartlett, 2018) Properties of Maximum likelihood estimators (MLE) From our lecture notes, MLE for large sample sizes possess the following characteristics: 1. Bias goes to 0 as sample size increases 2.
